question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable for demonstration. You are a data analysis expert, please help create an HTML-formatted rose chart for analyzing housing prices across 100 Chinese cities.

checklist.title: Is the rose chart visualization accurately implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code correctly implements a rose chart (polar area chart) using HTML/JavaScript/SVG or Canvas, with proper polar coordinate system transformation and radial data representation. Check if housing price data for 100 Chinese cities is properly mapped to angular segments and radial distances. Score 0 if basic chart structure is missing, 5 if only simple polar visualization is implemented, and 10 if complete rose chart with accurate data binding and polar geometry is fully implemented.

checklist.title: Is the housing price data structure properly designed and processed?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code includes appropriate data structures for storing 100 Chinese cities' housing price information (city name, price, region classification, etc.) and implements proper data preprocessing (normalization, sorting, grouping). Check if data validation and error handling for missing or invalid price data is included. Deduct 5 points if data structure is poorly designed, 3 points if no data validation exists. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Are interactive analysis features comprehensively implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether the rose chart includes essential interactive features: hover tooltips showing detailed city information, click-to-highlight specific cities or regions, zoom/pan capabilities, and filtering options (by price range, region, city tier). Evaluate if smooth transitions and animations are provided during interactions. Deduct 5 points if basic hover interactions are missing, 3 points if no filtering mechanism exists. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the data analysis functionality complete and insightful?
checklist.description: Assess whether the implementation provides meaningful analytical capabilities: statistical summaries (average, median, quartiles), regional comparisons, trend identification, and data export functionality. Check if the visualization effectively communicates housing price patterns across different city tiers and regions. Deduct 5 points if no statistical analysis is provided, 3 points if regional grouping is missing. Give 10 points if comprehensive analysis features are implemented.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as missing data points, invalid price values, browser compatibility issues, large dataset rendering performance) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the analysis experience (e.g., 1. Real-time price comparison with national average 2. Animated timeline showing price trends 3. Geographic clustering visualization 4. Price prediction indicators). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar chart types (e.g., multiple rose chart libraries coexisting) 2. Function modules unrelated to housing price analysis (e.g., built-in weather widgets) 3. Fancy effects that affect chart readability (e.g., excessive 3D transforms, distracting particle effects). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if core visualization functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data processing/visualization/interaction layers), reusable component structure, and proper documentation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or no separation of concerns exists; deduct 5 points if code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if no proper commenting or documentation exists. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern data visualization principles: 1) Harmonious color scheme suitable for data analysis (proper contrast ratios, colorblind-friendly palette) 2) Appropriate chart proportions and spacing (legend placement, axis labeling) 3) Professional typography system (readable font sizes ≥ 12px for labels, clear hierarchy). Deduct 3 points for each poorly designed visual element, 5 points for inappropriate color choices that hinder data interpretation, and 5 points for cluttered layout. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the chart interactions conform to data visualization best practices: 1) Hover feedback delay ≤ 100ms with smooth tooltip positioning 2) Transition animations for data updates controlled between 300-800ms 3) Clear visual feedback for all interactive elements 4) Smooth performance when handling 100 data points simultaneously. Deduct 5 points for each interaction without proper feedback, 3 points for laggy animations during data transitions, and 5 points for unclear interactive affordances. Full score is 10 points.
